speaker: therapist
text: Hello Alex. Welcome back. Before we begin, I want to check in with how you're feeling after our last session. That was deep, challenging work.

speaker: client
text: Hi Dr. Lee. Honestly, it was a rough week. I felt raw, like I'd poked at a bruise I didn't know was there. That exercise—adding 'and I remembered the coffee'—it was... strange. Sometimes it made me angry at you for suggesting it.

speaker: therapist
text: Thank you for your honesty. That anger is completely valid. When we challenge a long-held story, even a painful one, part of us rebels. It can feel like a betrayal. Can you tell me about a specific moment when that anger came up?

speaker: client
text: It was Thursday night. I couldn't sleep, and the guilt about the cereal was just looping in my head. I forced myself to say the coffee line, and I just felt this surge of irritation. Like, 'So what? Coffee doesn't cancel out cereal. This is a stupid game.' It felt cheap.

speaker: therapist
text: That's a crucial insight. The mind interprets it as a 'game' of cancellation, of score-keeping. That wasn't my intention. The goal isn't to cancel or keep score. It's to practice holding multiple truths at once. To expand the narrative from a single, punishing point of data. Did the feeling of it being 'cheap' persist?

speaker: client
text: For a while. But then... something else happened. I was cleaning out a drawer over the weekend and found a birthday card Jordan gave me. In it, he wrote, 'To my health nut - thank you for keeping me honest (and for secretly liking my cereal).'

speaker: therapist
text: Alex... may we pause there? That's a powerful discovery. What did you feel reading those words he wrote?

speaker: client
text: I broke down. But it was a different kind of crying. It wasn't the guilty, hot crying. It was... aching. He knew. He knew I teased him, and he called it 'keeping him honest.' He saw my secret liking of his silly joy. He framed it as a *gift* I gave him. Not a failure.

speaker: therapist
text: He reframed it for you. In his words, from the past, he offered a different narrative: one of playful partnership, of mutual understanding. This is what we mean by 'revising the story.' Not making things up, but uncovering other perspectives that have been buried by the loud voice of grief. How does it feel to hold his perspective alongside your guilty one?

speaker: client
text: It makes the guilty one feel... lonely. And a bit selfish, in a new way. Like I've been having this whole conversation in my head where I'm the judge and jury, and I never called the most important witness. Jordan himself.

speaker: therapist
text: That is an incredibly articulate and profound way to put it. Grief can create a solitary, interior trial. You've just invited the voice of the 'other' back into the room. Does his perspective in the card feel more 'true' to the relationship you actually lived?

speaker: client
text: Yes. It does. It feels like the truth of *us*. The guilt feels like the truth of my isolated, post-loss mind. They're different truths.

speaker: therapist
text: This is the core of the work. Integrating the 'truth of us' back into your current reality, where the 'truth of the isolated mind' has taken over. The card is a tangible piece of evidence for the compassionate narrative. Would you be willing to explore a small creative exercise with me now, building on this?

speaker: client
text: Okay. What kind of exercise?

speaker: therapist
text: It's a narrative technique. Let's give that guilty, repetitive thought in the cereal aisle a name. Not an aggressive name, but a descriptive one. What would you call that voice that says, 'You should have bought it more often'?

speaker: client
text: Hmm. It's the... Prosecutor. It's cold, it's building a case, it only presents one kind of evidence.

speaker: therapist
text: Perfect. 'The Prosecutor.' Now, based on the card, if Jordan could speak to the Prosecutor's claim, what might he say? Not to silence it, but to offer his evidence to the court.

speaker: client
text: (Closes eyes for a moment) He'd... probably roll his eyes and laugh softly. He'd say, 'Alex, my love, it was a box of cereal. The teasing was the flavor. I felt seen by it. You showed your love by remembering my coffee, by holding me through the worst of it. The cereal was the sprinkle on top.'

speaker: therapist
text: 'The teasing was the flavor. I felt seen by it.' That's a transformative reframe. Can you feel the difference in your body between the Prosecutor's statement and Jordan's imagined statement?

speaker: client
text: The Prosecutor makes me tense, tight in my shoulders. Jordan's words... they make my chest ache with missing him, but there's a warmth there. A sadness that's connected to love, not to failure.

speaker: therapist
text: You are distinguishing between two types of pain: the corrosive pain of self-condemnation and the connective, honest pain of love and loss. Your task is not to eliminate pain, but to slowly, gently guide yourself from the former toward the latter. The Prosecutor may always whisper, but now you have a new, more loving voice to call on—one built from the real history of your relationship.

speaker: client
text: It's tiring, having to build this new voice. The Prosecutor is so well-established, so automatic.

speaker: therapist
text: It is tiring, like building a new mental muscle. We don't do it all at once. For this week, I'd like to suggest something slightly different. When you notice The Prosecutor, don't engage in a debate. Simply acknowledge it: 'Ah, The Prosecutor is here.' Then, if you have the energy, ask yourself, 'What might Jordan's perspective be?' If you don't have the energy, that's okay. Just the act of naming The Prosecutor externalizes it—it becomes a *part* of your mind, not the whole of it.

speaker: client
text: Just name it. I can try that. It feels less like a battle and more like... observation.

speaker: therapist
text: Exactly. You are moving from being the defendant on trial to being the wise observer of your own internal process. That is a fundamental shift. How are you feeling as we wrap up today?

speaker: client
text: Less raw than last week. More... purposeful. Sad, but with a direction. The card... it was like getting a message. It hurt, but it was a good hurt.

speaker: therapist
text: A 'good hurt.' That is the pain of integration, of love persisting. You've done exceptional work these three sessions, Alex. You're not just grieving; you are carefully, bravely rebuilding a connection to your love that can coexist with your life now. Hold on to that card. It's a piece of your new anchor. I'll see you next week.
